description:
Mandrillus sphinx, commonly known as the mandrill, is a species of large, colorful Old World monkey found in the rainforests of Central Africa. It is the largest living member of the primate family Cercopithecidae and is known for its distinctive facial features and vibrant coloration.

The mandrill is characterized by a large, robust build with a prominent muzzle and a striking color pattern on its face and rump. The face is marked by a bright blue and red nose, cheeks, and chin, while the rump and genitals exhibit shades of red, purple, and blue. These vivid colors are believed to play a role in social communication and sexual display among the animals.

Mandrills are highly social and live in large, multi-male, multi-female troops, with a complex social hierarchy. They are primarily frugivorous, consuming a variety of fruits, leaves, and other plant matter, as well as occasionally preying on small vertebrates and invertebrates.

The species is classified as Vulnerable on the IUCN Red List due to habitat loss, fragmentation, and hunting pressures. Conservation efforts are ongoing to protect the mandrill and its rainforest habitat in Central Africa.
